ygData.subject: Re: [archive-crawler] Problem with mime-type
ygData.msgSnippet: I took a look and these are the response headers we re getting back: [Date: Tue, 05 Sep 2006 21:26:58 GMT , Server: Apache/2.0.59 (Unix) mod_ssl/2.0.59

Subject: Re: [archive-crawler] Problem with mime-type
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=168599281; y=igzCmGFWFQWXm57BQWQwaLg7VT9u3hkqniofWS1t7dz63qiQ5r5PqQFm
X-Yahoo-Profile: stackarchiveorg

I took a look and these are the response headers we're getting back:

[Date: Tue, 05 Sep 2006 21:26:58 GMT
, Server: Apache/2.0.59 (Unix) mod_ssl/2.0.59 OpenSSL/0.9.7g DAV/2 PHP/4.4.3
, X-Powered-By: PHP/4.4.3
, Set-Cookie: bi=0fabd70c899d0804ae49e3cadc359725; path=/
, Expires: Mon, 26 Jul 1997 05:00:00 GMT
, Cache-Control: post-check=0, pre-check=0, false
, Pragma: public
, Last-modified: Tue, 05 Sep 2006 21:26:59 GMT
, Content-Trensfer-Encoding: none
, Content-Disposition: attachment; filename="Disk_A_2.88_v12.zip";
, Content-length: 360888
, Connection: close
, Content-Type: name="Disk_A_2.88_v12.zip"
]

Looks like Content-Type is 'name="Disk_A_2.88_v12.zip"' according to the 
server.

I think for archival crawling, we'll probably want to save as mimetype 
whatever the remote server volunteered.  But for other types of 
crawling, it would make sense if we could replace nonsensical mimetypes 
with a no-type or some such, or better, run a mimetype interrogation of 
downloaded content and let operator choose whether to store the type 
volunteered by the server or that discovered by the mimetype guesser.

For now I've add your suggestion that mimetype be settable to the 
already existing RFE "[ 1185316 ] mime-type guesser/verifier" issue: 
http://sourceforge.net/tracker/index.php?func=detail&aid=1185316&group_id=73833&atid=539102.

Thanks,
St.Ack
